doc.title: Tonight (David Bowie album)
doc.text: . It followed his most commercially successful album

. He described the album
, released immediately after his previous album's tour wrapped up
, as an effort to

quot.text:
keep my hand in
, so to speak
,

doc.text: and to retain the new audience that he had recently acquired.

The album was a commercial success
, reaching

pagelink.id: List of UK Albums Chart number ones of the 1980s
pagelink.text: number-one in the UK Albums Chart

doc.text: . It has received mostly poor reviews from music critics and Bowie expressed dissatisfaction with it in later years. The album was re-mastered in 2018 and included in the Bowie box set

doc.text: in support of his previous album

He did not have much luck writing while on tour
, so he described the process of recording the album

Bowie purposefully sought to keep the sound of the band he had used on the previous album and tour
, feeling that the new fans he had accumulated would expect to hear the same thing on the new album that they'd heard before
, hence the inclusion of the

, but unlike most previous Bowie albums
, Bowie played no instruments on the record
, and in fact he delegated almost all responsibility for the music played to his musicians
, only occasionally offering critical input.
Bowie brought in Derek Bramble and

to produce the record
, the former receiving the nod from Bowie due to some of the demos he'd recently produced for English female singer

, Bowie prepared for the album by recording some demos beforehand
, this time showing up with 8 of the 9 songs that would appear on the album. This surprised collaborator

quot.text: it was the first time in the eleven years that I've been with the damn man that he's brought in anything.

doc.text:
spent a good deal of time in the studio with Bowie and the band while the album was being recorded
, stating

quot.text:
I worked extensively on that album. There's a lot more work there than is reflected in just the simple co
-writing credit for two songs and some of the old stuff.

When asked why Bowie included so much Pop-written material on the album
, Pop could only guess. I

doc.text:
think he just wanted the songs heard more
,

quot.text: a sentiment Bowie would mirror when covering Pop's

ref.text:
Amsterdam Glass Spider Press Conference
, 30 March 1987

cell.text: David Bowie Opens Up - A Little

attr.text:
took five weeks or something
, which for me is a really long time. I like to work fast in the studio. There wasn't much of my writing on it 'cause I can't write on tour and I hadn't assembled anything to put out. But I thought it a kind of violent effort at a kind of

doc.text:
Some of the demo tracks were not yet named
, but they were numbered
, called simply

quot.text:
as a very personal bit of writing that he did not feel fit in with the rest of the album because it is such a dark song amidst lighter fare. He said
,

came about because of my feeling that so much history is wrong
- as is being rediscovered all the time
- and that we base so much on the wrong knowledge that we've gleaned.

doc.text: Bowie cut the demo for the song in

, Switzerland
, with a guitarist and a drummer he had drafted from a local Swiss band.

were not finished for the album
, much to Padgham's regret. He said
:

Three songs were covers of older Iggy Pop songs
:

quot.text:
, the latter of which stands out as a track Bowie wished he had not done
, with him later calling it disastrous

doc.text:
's one I wish I'd never touched
, or at least touched it differently. It went totally wrong. It sounded so tight and compromised
, and it was such a gas doing it. It was the wrong band to do it with
-- wonderful band
, but it wasn't quite right for that song.

, co
-written with Pop
, recounts the pair's exploits while vacationing in the Indonesian islands
after Bowie's previous tour had ended.
, which was one of Bowie's returns to a
tried it every which way. I tried it
, and then I just hit on an old

-sounding beat
, and it picked up life. Taking energy away from the musical side reinforced the lyrics and gave them their own energy. I think working with Derek Bramble helped because he played propper reggae bass lines.

, the title track and the other reggae-style track on the album
, Bowie eliminated Pop's original spoken word introduction
, calling it an

quot.text:
seemed not part of my vocabulary. ... I guess
[removing the spoken introduction
] changed the whole sentiment around. It still has that same barren feeling
, but it's out of that specific area that I'm not at home in.

doc.text:
Pop approved of Bowie's changes. For the vocals to the song
, Bowie and

sang face-to-face
, although Bowie went back and re-recorded the first verse after deciding to sing his part in a higher octave.

, which Bowie also co
-wrote with Pop
, was written and recorded in eight hours as they egged each other on. In what was described as an

quot.text:
went in
[to the studio
] with a few bottles of beer and would virtually bellow out anything that came into their heads
,
And I just recorded it all.

doc.text:
The lyrics were taken from a backlog of unused lyrics
; the line

quot.text: Your family is a football team

doc.text:
was a reference to the immigrant families working in New York
;

The track elicited this from Bowie
:

attr.text:
They were really just jams. David had some riffs on a tape
, in his head
, and the band would jam on them and we'd make a bit of a song out of it. But they were quite raunchy songs. At one point
, David asked me what my least favourite song out of the eleven or twelve we had was
, and I said 'Blue Jean.' I thought it was a bit lightweight. I would have rather had
in its place. I couldn't tell you why he didn't put them on the album. But I would have loved to have finished them.

There's a particular sound I'm after that I haven't really got yet
; I'll either crack it on the next album or retire from it. I think I got quite close to it on

over the last couple of years
- trying to write musically and develop things the way people used to write in the Fifties. I stayed away from experimentation. Now
, I think I should be a bit more adventurous. And in

Iggy and I broke away from all that for one track
, and it came nearer to the sound I was looking for than anything else.

doc.text:
Three singles were released from the album
:

quot.text:
in turn spawned several videos
, including an elaborate
which was described as more of a

doc.text:
than a video
, and represented Bowie's interest in making actual movies.

Despite some positive reviews of the album
,
other reviewers criticised it for lacking creativity

. Padgham
, who co
-produced the album
, also said that it was less innovative than other Bowie albums.

quot.text: one of the weakest albums Bowie ever recorded
none of the material equals the songs on
, although he made an exception for Blue

quot.text: an expensive quickie padded with lame covers

doc.text:
stated in a retrospective of Bowie's career in 2016
:

Bowie would later distance himself from the album
, acknowledging that it was not one of his stronger efforts.

quot.text:
There's stuff on
[the album
] that I could really kick myself about. When I listen to those demos it's
, 'How did it turn out like that?' You should hear

doc.text:
on demo. It's wonderful on demo. I promise you!
(laughs
). But on the album
, it's
... not as wonderful.

Despite the general consensus on the album
,
reviewed the album in 2005 as part of its

, although not a great album
, is still a good one
:

quot.text:
it’s a much better album than you think it is
, or may have been led to believe. Bowie’s made some subpar records
, but this isn't one of them
—and frankly
, even its failures aren't boring
, because
, well
, it’s an '80s Bowie album
, from a decade in which he was wildly inconsistent
, but also never dull.
no album that begins with the seven-minute masterpiece 'Loving the Alien' and contains the rocking 'Blue Jean' should have received the drubbing it got

doc.text:
' is as stirring
, in its cold
, almost
